title: Significant Differences in Word Recognition Scores
chief_complaint: I am having increased difficulty recognizing speech in noise and understanding female talkers. I also have trouble communicating on the telephone.

problem_summary.onset: Long-standing hearing loss; recent decline noted in 2012.
problem_summary.course: Stable from 2007 to 2011, followed by a significant decline in the right ear in 2012.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Fullness in the right ear; no tinnitus, vertigo, or dizziness reported.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty with speech in noise and telephone use; physical difficulty inserting right hearing aid due to ear canal narrowing.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: To determine if hearing changes require hearing aid adjustments.

history.prior_management: None prior; fit with bilateral hearing aids following this visit.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal limits 250-2000 Hz bilaterally. Right: Moderate to moderate-severe SNHL 3-8 kHz. Left: Mild to moderate-severe SNHL 3-8 kHz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs within normal limits. WRS showed slight difficulty in the right ear and normal ability in the left.

history.otologic_history: Patient underwent Mohs micrographic surgery for basal cell carcinoma of the right concha AFTER this exam.
history.prior_management: Using bilateral hearing aids with thin tubes and open earmolds.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: WRS scores slightly reduced from baseline but stable compared to previous year (2010).

history.otologic_history: Post-Mohs surgery (2011). Right external meatus narrowed with prolapsing conchal cartilage. Patient reports sensation of fullness in right ear.
history.prior_management: Right hearing aid coupled with thin tube and small dome due to canal narrowing preventing custom mold use.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows 10 dB decrease at 250 Hz and 3000-4000 Hz compared to previous. Left ear stable.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Significant decrease in Right WRS (40% drop). Non-significant decrease in Left WRS (12% drop).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Contralateral reflexes absent/elevated bilaterally. Ipsilateral absent right 500-4000 Hz. Abnormal reflex decay in right ear at 1000 Hz.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Delayed absolute latencies for Wave V bilaterally. Absent Wave I and II right ear. No strong indication of central dysfunction, but CT scan ordered to confirm.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with bilateral asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss. While thresholds have remained relatively stable with only minor shifts, there is a statistically significant decline in word recognition scores in the right ear (dropping from 80% to 40% over one year). The left ear shows a smaller decline (82% to 70%) which is not statistically significant based on critical difference tables. Acoustic reflex decay was positive in the right ear.
counseling_points: The drop in your word recognition score in the right ear is statistically significant and warrants medical investigation.
The change in the left ear score is within the range of expected variability and is not considered a significant decline.
We are referring you to an otologist to investigate the asymmetry and the reflex decay findings.
The CT scan and ABR results help rule out retrocochlear pathology (like a tumor) despite the changes in your hearing scores.
notes_for_actor: You have had skin cancer surgery on your right ear which makes the ear canal feel 'full' and tight.
You are not dizzy and do not have tinnitus.
You are concerned because you are struggling more to understand speech, especially in noise or on the phone.
